Expectation1: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation1: The routine maintenance checklist is coming up soon, but no malfunctions have been noted.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the lab wall, heart pounding. The maintenance checklist was due in half an hour, and as the lead scientist, I was expected to double-check every safety protocol, even if nothing seemed amiss. My team relied on me to keep the lab running smoothly and safely. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: today was election day, and I had promised myself I’d vote. I rushed to the polling station, only to be told by an official that my registration had a mismatch. If I wanted my vote to count, I had to fill out a provisional ballot form—right now, before the station closed in ten minutes. I stared at the form, my mind racing. If I stayed, I might miss the lab’s maintenance window, risking safety violations. If I left, I’d forfeit my vote, betraying my civic duty. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each with consequences I couldn’t ignore. My hands trembled as I tried to decide which responsibility I owed more in this moment.
